Because the Government failed to find the yield to fund the tax cuts in the way they said they would and said that they had done, they had to look elsewhere for revenue. They got it in two places. They increased borrowing and VAT receipts. Both of these measures run absolutely counter to the commitments made to our EC partners and are totally inconsisent with the obligations the Government intend undertaking under the Treaty of Maastricht. It is not generally realised that as a result of the Taoiseach's last budget and the first budget of the Minister for Finance, Deputy Ahern, the real EBR has been doubled in the last two years. This has been done at a time when the Government are committed to a balanced budget in 1993 and when they are urging the electorate to undertake the far more onerous target of reducing the debt as a percentage of Gross National Product to 60 per cent by 1997.

This Finance Bill and the budget it underpins are not consistent with the achievement of these targets. They are not consistent with European economic and monetary union. They are not consistent with the Government advocacy of a yes vote on the referendum on 18 June next and they are certainly not consistent with prudent domestic fiscal policy.

This strategy might be acceptable if the increase in EBR was merely a once off blip in a declining graph but, on the Minister's own admission, next year will be a particularly tight fiscal year. The full year effect of the Government's increased expenditure programme must be paid for. For example, the £168 million which the income tax package cost in nine months this year will cost £260 million in a full year, on the Government's own figures. The public service pay which the Government deferred to next year must be paid. The loss of revenue due to the abolition of VAT at the point of entry must be made good. The loss of revenue for the changes announced in the DIRT in this Finance Bill must be made good and the Government must fulfil their medium term target of a balanced budget.

I think this is mission impossible. I suspect that the Taoiseach and the Minister for Finance know this quite well; that it is their fullest intention to cut and run to the country at the first available opportunity in the autumn in the hope that if they win the election they can inflict a programme of austerity on this country without fear of the electorate but if on the other hand they lose, as has been the tradition of the Minister's party, they will leave the unpalatable tasks to other people.

The third adverse effect of the Government's failure to fund their income tax reductions by the abolition of tax breaks and reliefs, as they said they would, is that they have raided VAT receipts to do so. The Government have a stated commitment and obligation to our European Community partners to simplify the VAT code and to introduce two rates of VAT — a higher standard rate and a lower rate for a small number of goods and services.

Some progress towards these ends was made in recent budgets but this progress was cancelled out in the last budget and in this Finance Bill. The 12.5 per cent rate of VAT is being increased to 16 per cent and the proceeds are not to be used, as everybody expected, to reduce the 21 per cent rate but to fund the Progressive Democrats income tax package which they could not fund, as they said they would, by abolishing tax breaks and reliefs and dealing with tax avoidance.

Rather than simplifying the VAT code by having two rates — which is what the Government are committed to doing — we will have six VAT rates; the 2.7 per cent rate at which farmers will receive a rebate, the zero rate which applies in respect of 44 per cent of public consumption, the 10 per cent rate, the 12,5 per cent rate, the 16 per cent rate and the 21 per cent rate. If we are to believe the Government, this is progress towards tax harmonisation, two VAT rates and a simpler VAT code.

I was amused by one aspect of the Minister's speech. He said that the zero rating for corn-based and maize-based snacks is to be abolished — Deputy Foxe will appreciate this as he was a member of the trade before he became a Member of this House. Is this the Minister who will go down in history as the man who taxed peanuts? That is what he seems to have in mind in abolishing the zero rating for corn-based products.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Rabbitte Mr. Rabbitte
Speaker.P: Sheep feed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): The most tragic effect of the behaviour of the Government is that there is not one single job creation measure in the budget, while several sections of this Finance Bill are going to cost us jobs. Enterprise and risk taking are discouraged while sedentary or low-risk activity is encouraged. The changes in VAT and taxation on holiday cottages will have an adverse effect on the tourism industry. Co-op tax, tax on company cars, capital gains tax relief and the increase in the cost of a pub licence, which will result in some pubs being closed, will cost us jobs. Yet, I cannot identify one single proposal anywhere in the Finance Bill which is specifically geared towards creating a single job anywhere in the country.

MainHeading.P: Nothing illustrates the Government's attitude to enterprise and risk taking and to investment in job creation better than the changes announced in the deposit interest retention tax in the Finance Bill. Persons who put their savings into certain deposit accounts will pay income tax at the rate of 10 per cent on unearned income up to approximately £5,000 for a single person or £10,000 for a married couple. If a married couple have £100,000 either here or abroad and put it into one of the Minister's new special deposit accounts they will pay tax at the rate of 10 per cent and this will fulfil their total tax liability on unearned income because, as the Minister stated in his speech again today, there will be no requirement to make any return on that income to the Revenue Commissioners.

If a person is working they will be taxed at the rate of 27 per cent or 48 per cent but if a person has unearned income or money on deposit they will pay at the rate of 10 per cent. If a person has savings and wants to invest them, first they will accept the risk in making the investment in the free market economy and if they make a profit they will be taxed at the marginal rate, which will be either 27 per cent or, more likely, 48 per cent. Yet, if a person sits at home and leaves the money in one of the Minister's special deposit accounts they will pay at the rate of 10 per cent.

The banks are picking up this ball already. I am aware that certain banking people are already saying that they will introduce special deposit schemes under which they will give a person 10 per cent net straight up and meet the tax liability themselves. Is this consistent with a society where there is record unemployment and where investment is necessary to create jobs with the rewards being geared towards sedentary and low-risk activity? All the savings will not be put into the Minister's new deposit accounts as the money will have to be left on deposit for three months in the first instance and a month's notice will be required before it can be withdrawn but in relation to normal deposit accounts with the banks and building societies deposit interest retention tax will be deducted at the standard rate of income tax, 27 per cent. Again, this will meet the full liability and there will be no requirement to make a return to the Revenue commissioners on the interest earned on such deposit accounts.

I should make the point that this is the wrong balance in a system where unearned income will be taxed at the rate of 10 per cent or 27 per cent depending on where a person puts it and earned income will be taxed at 27 per cent or 48 per cent. I know what the Minister is trying to do; he is trying to protect the revenue yield but in protecting the revenue yield he will distort the savings market in the country to such a degree that he will slow down the rate of activity.

The advantage now rests with the “do nothing” sector of society who have money rather than with the risk takers, the enterprise people and all those who were held up as role models as recently as last week by the Minister for Education who expects every teacher in the country to be a promoter of the enterprise culture and entrepreneurship, even with four year olds.

This measure does not make sense. It is anti-jobs, anti-enterprise and anti-risk taking. It will reinforce attitudes and certain sedentary activities and will not create any jobs. I do not think anything could be framed in a manner which is more likely to discourage risk taking and enterprise than this measure which outlines the way DIRT will be dealt with in the future.

There is a similar discouragement for small investors in the equity market and the balance of advantage has been swung by the Minister in favour of deposit accounts and against investment in equities. Everyone will not set up their own business and working people have a day's work to do but some people who have money to spare might buy a few shares in the banks or manufacturing industry in any of our publicly quoted companies. This small injection of capital by numerous small savers could be the investment which creates jobs but what does the Minister do? He has decided to halve the relief on capital gains which small savers could avail of.

As we are all aware, small savers cannot get into the gilt market at present as there is no real gilt market for small savers. Neither is there any market for the small saver at present in Government paper as it is monopolised by the big players. This is an item which has been raised time and again. Therefore it will not be invested in Government paper or in the gilt market while it is unlikely that it will be put into self-generating new risk enterprises; rather it will be put into the Minister's new deposit accounts. The Revenue Commissioners and the people responsible in the Department of Finance will be happy that the yield from DIRT will be saved but where is the enterprise, risk taking, investment and job creation as we move inexorably towards a figure of 300,000 unemployed? This measure will have to be reconsidered.

I would like to ask the Minister one question at this stage which he may answer on Thursday. Is it also the intention, at 10 per cent or at 27 per cent, apart from the fact that there will be no further tax liability for the person with money on deposit, that the Revenue Commissioners will not look behind the money at any future stage and, because it will not, be notifiable, that no attempt will be made to see whether this money was taxed previously?

We are talking about the Minister organising a scheme because he is faced with removing exchange controls. He has to bring down the rate of DIRT so he is trying to broaden the base by allowing shifty people, who did not pay their taxes, to bring their money back and to put it into deposit accounts here. It is a question of getting the hot money back to this country where it will attract a guaranteed 10 per cent interest rate. It is that kind of hot money, chance-my-arm culture, which has left this country in the State it is and it is being encouraged by one of the few officers of Government specifically mentioned in the Constitution.

I do not see a single job creation measure in the Finance Bill. It is difficult to see how 15 persons in Cabinet, all of whom no doubt agree that unemployment is the greatest problem facing the country, can have sat idly by while this blueprint for joblessness passed before them. The Progressive Democrats, of course, will claim that the tax reform proposals, which systematically reduce the marginal rate of tax, even though most taxpayers continue to pay the same — or extra — taxation, will put people back to work. We have been preached at by the Progressive Democrats inside and outside this House for many years on the connection between the marginal rate of tax and job creation. They have elevated the reduction of the marginal rate of tax and the idea of the tax wedge to a kind of new Jerusalem status. As in other matters, they have totally over-sold their case, their claims at this stage are downright dishonest. Could someone on the Government side — preferably a Progressive Democrat Minister — answer the following simple question? If there is such a close connection between the marginal rate of tax and job creation why, when over the last few years the standard rate of income tax was reduced from 35 per cent to 27 per cent and the higher rate brought down to 48 per cent, was it accompanied by the highest level of unemployment since the State was founded in 1922? I thought the theory was that if you brought the marginal rates down jobs will be created in parallel. Now that the rate has been reduced from 35 per cent to 27 per cent where are the jobs? Could somebody also explain how a further reduction in marginal rates of tax, from 27 per cent to 25 per cent and from 48 per cent to 44 per cent, will suddenly press the magic trigger of job creation? When the large adjustment of a reduction from 35 per cent to 27 per cent did not work, how will the small adjustment from 27 per cent to 25 per cent suddenly create a boost in job creation? It is time to admit that they based their high-falut in theory on very slim evidence. It has now been put to the practical test and there is really no connection between the marginal rate of tax and job creation.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Rabbitte Mr. Rabbitte
Speaker.P: Fianna Fáil do not believe those things.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): In fairness, they do not believe them. They think that policy is a load of nonsense but, for political reasons, they were not prepared to stand up and be counted in regard to the issue. They went along with the charade. I am not stretching the argument so far as to say that because the standard rate of tax was reduced from 35 per cent to 27 per cent it caused job losses. However, it did not prevent job losses nor did it create extra jobs. The whole question of job creation is far more complex than the simplistic theories of tax reform advocated inside and outside this House, particularly by the Progressive Democrats, in the most strident, hectoring fashion. They have been totally ineffective in terms of delivery. It is about time the Progressive Democrats admitted that their tax policy is ineffective, it is a big propaganda lie. It is not capable of creating the major, dramatic, economic change which its proponents claim.

When the Finance Bill was published I was amused by some of the Minister's PR people who covered him in a very resolute cloak because he insisted on implementing some of his dafter budgetary proposals, “Bertie is not for turning” kind of thing. I have always believed that if one is mistaken it is not a particular virtue to insist that you will not change your mind. If one is wrong in January surely there is no great merit in repeating the mistake in April and looking for praise for it? There was merit in the cases put forward by many of the lobby groups on this occasion, particularly by sales representatives, publicans, members of co-operatives and small investors and the Minister should have listened to them.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Ahern Mr. B. Ahern
Speaker.P: I did make changes in relation to some of them.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): They were marginal changes. In fairness, the Minister listened and improved the situation in relation to share options, which is welcome. I now want to turn to specific items in the Bill, I should like to refer to the income tax sections first. It is quite clear that I do not believe in the Progressive Democrats approach and the Fianna Fáil part of the Government should not allow it to continue.

It is not the rate at which one pays tax which is the problem, it is the amount paid as a proportion of one's total income. The point at which one starts to pay income tax and the point at which one pays the higher rate are also important. People pay tax at 27 per cent plus full PRSI on too low an income, at a point where they should not be paying tax of any kind. The first thing is to take more people out of the tax net and any resources available should be directed towards this end. If that proves too expensive I advise the Minister to take a leaf out of Norman Lamont's book and do what we proposed in one of our policy documents before the local elections. The Minister should implement an introductory tax rate to help the lower paid. Mr. Lamont brought in an introductory rate of 20 per cent; if we had an introductory rate of 15 per cent, even on £500 or £1,000 of taxable income, it would cost less than trying to expand the reliefs to take people out of the tax net. If we had such a rate it would mean that the people would pay 15 per cent, not 34.5 per cent. The next biggest problem is the jump from 27 per cent to 48 per cent; people on quite modest incomes — especially single people — are forced into paying tax at the rate of 48 per cent on very low incomes. Any resources available should be applied to widening the standard rate, indeed 80 per cent to 85 per cent of taxpayers should pay income tax at the standard rate or less if we have a new introductory rate. Only 15 per cent should pay tax at a higher rate.

MainHeading.P: I do not think it matters very much whether the higher rate is 44 per cent, 55 per cent or more, provided it applies only to a small percentage of taxpayers. That should be the approach instead of this ideologically driven course which the former Member of this House — now the chairman of the Progressive Democrats — espouses by saying week after week that we must get the rate down to 40 per cent and then to 25 per cent. He seems to think it is like Moses striking the rock for the fourth time, that water will flow; it will not. It will not make a blind bit of difference to the economy or to job creation. It will also make very little difference to the amount of tax which people pay because if you bring down the marginal rates, refuse to index the allowances and bands and abolish relief it means it is all swings and roundabouts. You are giving the appearance of reform when there is none.

It is now coming to the point where the ordinary taxpayer does not believe any commitment about tax reform. They hear good news in the last days of January but when they receive their tax free allowances from the Revenue Commissioners in April they find they are usually paying more. Frequently, they pay more because the level has gone up and because, having benefited from non-payment of PRSI for the final two months of the year, PRSI payments are recommenced in April.

The concept of tax reform is now falling into disrepute. Relief should first be given to those who are least capable of paying the tax. The Government should try to take more of those people out of the tax net. If resources are limited, an introductory rate of somewhere between 10 per cent and 20 per cent could be introduced as a matter of principle on a small tranche of income, even if the level is set at only £500. Once the scheme is established, either the Minister, or his successor, could expand it; once it exists it would move. It would make sense for the Minister to introduce this concept in his second Finance Bill in the autumn and after achieving a level of 25 per cent or 27 per cent, for example, the scope of the initiative could be widened until it applied to about 80 per cent of taxpayers. After that was done, most people — including myself — would not be bothered if the top rate was pitched at 50 per cent. There is nothing sacrosanct about pulling the top rate down to 40 per cent.

I know it is now fashionable to say that tax reliefs are bad and should be abolished and that people should have more discretion over their spending power. The idea is to give people money and allow them to spend it in whatever way they like. Apparently, that is good tax policy. People like me who advocate tax allowances and reliefs are considered old-fashioned and not in tune with the modern world. I believe it is good tax policy to encourage people to buy their own homes, to insure themselves, and their families, against illness and to make provision for their spouses and their orphans if they die.

I do see what it does for society to abolish tax relief on life assurance premiums, mortage interest or VHI in order to distribute the proceeds to taxpayers in general. That transfer is easy to follow: in general terms, it is a transfer from the prudent to the imprudent. Often there is a transfer from householders to non-householders and from married people to single people. We have all sown our wild oats in our twenties — and some people are still sowing them — but we must recognise that the discretionary income of young people goes into entertainment, foreign holidays, drink, cigarettes and records. The common element of those expenses is that they are not good for the balance of trade — money goes out of the country. It is grand to have the theory that money should be given to the punters so that they may make their own consumption choices but that is bad social and economic policy. I would prefer to encourage people to provide houses for themselves, health insurance cover for them and their families and assistance for their spouses and children in the event of their death, a provision that was abolished in the Bill.

I am prepared to accept the argument that people on a marginal rate of 48 per cent should not get back £48 out of every £100 while those on a marginal rate of 27 per cent get back only £27 out of every £100. There is no reason that taxpayers on a low marginal rate should receive benefit worth £27 for every £100 spent on VHI while those on a high marginal tax rate receive benefit worth £48 for every £100 spent on such cover. It is necessary to adjust that anomaly and make the position fairer. However, the principle of allowances is part of the portfolio of tax policy in every modern developed state. One can argue about which allowances should be retained but I cannot accept the principle that by definition allowances are wrong and we should give the people the money to spend as they wish.

The same argument holds in terms of regional policy. Different fiscal stances feature in the portfolio of regional policy in any modern state. That has been the case here. Higher incentives were given along the west cost compared to those given on the east coast. That also can be good policy. Special concessions — some of which are being taken away by the Bill — were given to Shannon Airport for specific economic effect. Some are being provided for developments in the centre of Dublin in the Financial Services Centre, along the quays, and in the Temple Bar area. Those incentives are being provided to get a specific economic effect from a special tax relief. We could argue about the merits and demerits of the incentives but, as a matter of principle, the incentives are an instrument of fiscal policy and economic and social development that no Minister for Finance should let out of his hand. Tax reliefs and incentives should be evaluated on their merits. The general attitude that any relief is bad and means that someone is on the fiddle, even if he is only trying to provide a house and take out VHI cover for his wife and family, is wrong.

Section 6 amends the tax rate on pension contributions rebated on redundancy. The rate is being changed from 10 per cent to 25 per cent. I do not agree with the provision but at least the Minister is providing for those who have made application before budget date. Those people will now get the rebate at the 10 per cent rate. I request the Minister to make a further adjustment: will he also concede the 10 per cent rate for those who were made redundant in the 1991 tax year but have not applied? In that way, those who became redundant last January and had not applied for the rebate of pension contributions before the Minister made his unexpected announcement in the budget would get a rebate at a 10 per cent rate rather than at a 25 per cent rate. I make that request without prejudice to other views I hold and shall express on Committee Stage.

I thank the Minister for his initiative in relation to company cars. I know there was a very strong lobby in that regard but I do not consider the Minister went far enough. He should try to distinguish between those who use their cars as a tool of their trade and those who get a car from their employer merely as a perk. There is a great difference between an executive who drives to work in the city, leaves the car in free parking all day and does not use it for work purposes and someone who uses his car for work five days a week. Many of my constituents would be catered for if account was taken of mileage, as many of them clock up high mileages driving around the country from Limerick. However, basing the relief on mileage would not cater for Dublin-based people who might work in the city, spending half of their time in traffic and often parking their cars near the Ilac Centre and then walking. Such workers who may have a mileage of only 9,000 or 10,000 miles a year use their cars as their office, their store and the place from which they work five days of the week. Tapering relief on high mileage would not meet the needs of those people. The only way to be fair is to make a distinction between those who get a car as a perk and those who use a car as a tool of their trade. Such definition would not be beyond the capability of the very good civil servants in the Department of Finance and the Revenue Commissioners.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Ahern Mr. B. Ahern
Speaker.P: That point can be discussed later. I take the Deputy's point but a detailed examination might show that the difficulty has to do with the figures.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): Section 13 abolishes the relief that enabled individual shareholders in companies to receive up to £9,000 in dividend income free of tax. Many small family businesses were making use of this provision as a way of making ends meet. I should like the Minister to reconsider his decision to abolish this relief. I have had correspondence from a husband and wife team who say this provision will cost them near enough to £18,000. In some circumstances this relief makes the difference between an organisation keeping going or having to close. Again a principle is being followed that is grand in theory but proves in practice to be anti-jobs. As I understand it, we are trying to encourage as many people as possible to look after themselves, to get out of the labour market if at all possible, to become self-employed. The scheme being abolished has worked. I am sure the yield from that move will be tiny and I consider this amendment to be ill-judged.

Section 17 amends the profit sharing scheme provisions by reducing the ceiling from £5,000 to £2,000. That is a welcome move and I thank the Minister for his response. I ask him to explain in more detail on Committee Stage.

I do not understand the reason for abolishing the tax breaks on patents in section 19. This move is also anti-jobs and anti-enterprise. The yield involved must be very low. This provision will hammer creative people, such as the person who works from a garage at the back of his house and may come up with a new idea. Abolishing the tax concession for such people was not a good move.

MainHeading.P: With regard to section 22 and the new provisions for DIRT, the Minister stated explicitly that there will be disclosure with regard to companies which avail of deposit accounts, but will there be disclosure for the ordinary deposit account saver? Will it be automatic disclosure by the banks and building societies or discretionary disclosure where they will be obliged to answer questions when asked? What is the connection between the Minister's proposal and a kind of amnesty for “black capital” which the Minister is trying to attract back into the country?

Section 24 is a bad provision. The tourist industry is one of the wheels on which our economy will have to turn. There is probably more potential there for activity and job creation than in either farming or manufacturing industry. Tourism has the advantage of being an industry which, in effect, brings its own regional policy. Often the most attractive parts of the country are the most deprived. Tourists not only bring money to the country but they distribute it widely in their travels.

One of the big problems in the tourism industry is that tourist accommodation has not been up to European standards. A great number of Irish people now avail of ferries and cross to England, France and Germany and they know the difference. People will no longer holiday here unless they get reasonable accommodation. They are not prepared to spend their holidays in accommodation which is significantly worse than they have at home. To put it bluntly, people want to wash themselves every morning while on holidays, and a swim is not an adequate substitute. Our accommodation, particularly in provincial towns, will have to be geared up to suit the tourist. Apart from Killarney, there is hardly a town which has brought accommodation up to standard. Bedroom accommodation is not of a sufficiently high standard to attract and satisfy European families which are coming here in increasing numbers.

The BES scheme was abolished for the tourism industry last year. This year the last remaining incentive providing a tax break to enable accommodation to fit into the more scenic parts of Ireland is being abolished. That is anti-jobs, a mistake, a foolish provision. Like many other parts of the Finance Bill, it shows a sort of begrudgery. That attitude is prevalent throughout the Finance Bill and it is more obvious in this Finance Bill than it has been in other Finance Bills. The yield from this provision is very small. It is ridiculous to say that one can write off the capital cost of holiday accommodation against the rental income generated by that accommodation, when we all know that the tourist season here is only about nine weeks. Effectively there is no write-off, and the attraction was that it could be written off against the investors other income.

We all know of young professional people, accountants and doctors who, in partnership, bought 14 or 15 holiday cottages because they were able to write off capital costs against income tax on their salaries. That is no longer possible and, with the abolition of the BES last year and the fact that Structural Funds cannot be used to upgrade tourist accommodation here, that is a bad blow to the tourism industry. It is not a very good idea.

With regard to section 32, investors in Shannon based companies have enjoyed a distribution of dividends, tax free for many years, and have made a lot of money from it. Mr. Tony Ryan is one of the main beneficiaries from this, but the same gentleman is putting all that money into Shannon Aerospace at the moment and he is on the way to creating 1,500 jobs. He says that if he could keep the business rolling, he could provide 10,000 jobs. Why cut off the benefit at this point when this activity is not being used only as a tax break? It is not as if there had been a loss to the Exchequer. The Minister should at least phase this provision over a number of years. That would meet some of the problems. Some of that money is already earmarked for job creation in the Shannon region.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: This has done more damage to Shannon than eliminating the stop-over.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): The potential for damage is very serious indeed. There is a set of proposals which could deliver 10,000 jobs in refurbishing aeroplanes and engines and in the fabrication of fuselages, the spraying of planes and so on. The project is well under way. The first trained people have already come out of FÁS courses and other people are training in Switzerland. I have no doubt that in three years time there will be 1,500 people involved in that activity and that the full potential is for 10,000 jobs. This has come about to a large extent from the reinvestment of the money which has excited such envy in some quarters, money which was taken out by the distribution of tax free dividends and which was being reinvested by individuals because of their commitment to their country.

Will the Minister comment on section 37 and its effect on the package of incentives and commitments already made by the IDA, because section 84 funding is always part of IDA packages in attracting foreign industry, particularly North American industry?

Many sections of the Bill are technical in nature and can be dealt with more fully on Committee Stage. However, I would refer briefly to section 45 which refers to the abolition of tax exemption on co-ops. There are publicly quoted co-ops and we can read in the financial pages of the newspapers how much profit some of them have made — they seem to be doing very well — but there are other co-ops about which we do not hear who are making very small profits and which are there, in effect, for the benefit of their members, the small farmers and fishermen along the west coast. I would suggest a different approach.

At the moment co-ops are exempt from corporation tax. In the first year, 75 per cent of the co-op activity should be exempt from tax; instead of a 100 per cent exemption there would be a 75 per cent exemption. They would pay 40 per cent tax on a quarter of their activities, which is a 10 per cent tax. A more satisfactory approach would be to introduce a phased system over a three year period to apply to the entire business. At the moment some manufacturing activity will automatically attract a 10 per cent rate whereas other non-manufacturing activities attract a 40 per cent rate. To go from zero to 10 per cent might be acceptable, but to go from zero to 40 per cent is a frightful jump.

MainHeading.P: Let us take some of the dairy co-ops as an example. We all know of the traditional reluctance of farmers to pay tax. At their board meetings, instead of allowing management to declare a profit which would be reinvested, they will take it out on the price of a gallon of milk; that is what will happen on the ground. They will ask why they should give this tax to the Government, why not give an extra 2p on the gallon of milk? They admit this will mean they will show lower profits and that there will be less for reinvestment.

I note that in the Bill the Minister has made provision to meet some of the problems of An Bord Bainne. He has endeavoured to meet another problem; bearing in mind peaks and valleys in the business, when a co-operative with a surplus of milk sells to another co-operative 25 miles down the road, that operation would be taxed at 40 per cent because it is a sale of milk; it is not a manufacturing activity. I note that the Minister has pulled back on that and will impose a tax of 10 per cent. I do not think the Minister's revision will work. Frequently what happens is that a co-operative does not sell to a co-operative; they sell into the processing section of another co-operative which is usually incorporated as a company rather than as a co-operative. The Minister will have to change the definitions if his intention is to bring this into the 10 per cent bracket. In practice, the Minister's definition does not catch such activity; these activities will still be taxed at 40 per cent even though it is the Minister's intention to exempt them. Perhaps the Minister would examine that as well.

If the Minister adopted the proposal I am suggesting, I predict there would not be a loss of revenue; I predict the yield would be 10 per cent across the board from all such activity and that would be much neater and easier, from an administrative point of view rather than endeavouring to identify which activities would be taxed at 10 per cent and which at 40 per cent.

I have referred already to the provisions of section 57. I cannot understand why the tax relief on capital gains will be reduced from £2,000 to £1,000 in the case of an individual and from £4,000 to £2,000 in the case of a married couple. I have been in the habit of buying a few shares, but I have not been sufficiently lucky to benefit from this type of relief consistently. There is a decision in principle to be taken. If the Minister is endeavouring to encourage people to invest in a small way, if he is endeavouring to go down the road to some kind of shareholders' democracy, then the only thing in it for many people is the possibility of a capital gain which would be tax free, and the Minister is having that. When one considers that with what the Minister is doing on the deposit interest retention tax side, the combined effect will be to transfer the kind of discretionary savings of individuals into deposit accounts out of where there is a bit of play to generate economic activity. I would be interested to know the estimated yield because I predict it would be quite low.

I have not yet come to terms with Chapter V which seems to be long and involved. The petroleum taxation provisions of Chapter VI, to a large extent, appear to be a rerun of the 1985 amendment we produced when in Government but did not enact for one reason or another and will warrant scrutiny on Committee Stage. I do not intend dealing with them now.

The duties on beer seem to be of no practical relevance, rather they appear to be a vehicle being prepared for the future because the Minister has not been able to nominate the rate of excise duty which will apply to beer. This appears to be the new formula for its application.

It would appear the Minister has moved significantly on the pub licence provision which is helpful. I hope he will not experience a problem with its application because it is difficult to measure turnover. I have one question to pose here: the Minister spoke of activities other than the sale of drink being exempt. Does that include food?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Ahern Mr. B. Ahern
Speaker.P: Where food forms part of the pub activities.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): Will providing lunches tap into the turnover?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Ahern Mr. B. Ahern
Speaker.P: Yes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): What about the fellow with a licence running the disco? Will the £8 entry fee comprise part of the turnover?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Ahern Mr. B. Ahern
Speaker.P: If it is a late night disco it will be a separate fee, a more expensive one, which is included already.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): I know it is there already but, what will be the position in the calculation of the licence fee based on turnover? Suppose that weekly there is a sing-song in the back of a pub, and there is a cover charge, does the cover charge feature in the turnover or is it a separate item? The Minister might think about that.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Ahern Mr. B. Ahern
Speaker.P: It is related to the pub activity as distinct from that of a shop.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: But would there be singing if the premises were not licensed?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Foxe Mr. Foxe
Speaker.P: A person would not sing if he were not half-jarred.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): I have said what I wanted to say about the sections dealing with VAT with this exception: I presume it is the intention to introduce more wide ranging VAT provisions in the autumn in the second Finance Bill in that there will be a major loss of revenue when VAT at point of entry is abolished. Will it amount to something of the order of £200 million?

MainHeading.P: There is a proposal abroad — I would like to know what weight it has in departmental thinking — that in the autumn the Minister intends to introduce a scheme whereby he would recoup a full month's VAT by moving to monthly rather than bi-monthly collection. That rumoured proposal is causing much anxiety among people dependent on cash flow. The proposal would appear to be that one would pay two months' VAT today and, in a month's time, one would pay another month's VAT and continue to pay monthly thereafter. The effect of that would be that the Exchequer would get one full month's VAT once off. Will the Minister say whether that will happen because people would need advance notice of such a proposal, it would not want to be sprung on them in the autumn?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: It is going to happen.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): I would like confirmation. I do not think it has been said officially, but rather by way of general comment. Perhaps the Minister would confirm whether I am correct in that respect.

With regard to the provisions of section 183, I do not understand the anxiety of the Department of Finance to go after cash and credit cards since the yield cannot be great, especially the £2 stamp duty on ATM cards at a time when, I understand, we are encouraging the banks to move towards technological services, ease of service and all the rest, without prejudice to the recent strike. This was introduced before when Commissioner MacSharry was Minister for Finance and there was a stand-off. Those were the sterling days of the Tallaght strategy when we had more influence over policy than we do now because there was the threat of bringing down the Government. The proposal was dropped at that stage. I wonder was there someone in the Department of Finance awaiting a second chance under a majority Government. I do not think the imposition stands on its merits. The idea that it would not apply to any deposit account which had a positive balance, on a daily average, not exceeding £10 seems ludicrous. It begs the question: who in the name of God could use a cash card if the daily average balance in the account never exceeded £10?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: Myles na gCopaleen is alive an well in the Department of Finance.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): Could the Minister explain that to me? If the daily average balance in an account does not exceed £10, the ATM card will not be subjected to duty at all; that is the exemption proposed. That is a most peculiar provision. The Minister should abolish it because I cannot foresee the yield.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Ahern Mr. B. Ahern
Speaker.P: Thousands of accounts fall into that category. It has been brought to my attention that the banks, by way of promotional activities, issue such cards to schoolchildren. There would be thousands of schoolchildren holding those cards who would have no balance in their accounts. The proposal is designed to exempt such cardholders.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): That is a reasonable explanation.

In respect of Part V the revised residential property tax is not a proposal in respect of which we would want to salute the flag. It would appear to be the introduction of a seriously based property tax, now being pulled down to the level at which one wonders whether any house in Dublin will be exempt henceforth. I predict there would be very few; anyway, the whole south side of the city would be pulled into the net. I know there is an income ceiling of £27,500 and the commitment that the income limit will be index-linked in future years would appear to be less than strong. Any of us who have examined these matters would be forced to come to the conclusion that if a Government wanted to introduce a property tax this is the most convenient vehicle because the law exists already. All one has to do is change the ceilings both in respect of the market value of the property and the annual income. There is a big pull-down on it this year. I presume the exemption for children still applies; there is no variation in that respect.

MainHeading.P: I welcome the anti-avoidance measures in Part VII. I have not gone through them in detail but welcome them generally. On previous occasions I opposed anti-avoidance proposals when the fears I expressed transpired not to have been well founded because the Revenue Commissioners did not do the extravagant things various professionals predicted they would. I predict the only way self-assessment will work is if the Revenue Commissioners have the most rigorous powers to collect; to put it bluntly, it will be the terror of the Revenue only that will render many taxpayers compliant. I predict self-assessment will have to be like the Inland Revenue in the United States where, if a person sees one of their inspectors on the street, he crosses to the other side, his knees shaking and, where if they knock on your door, you are on the fringe of an emotional breakdown. It would be only by rigorous powers of collection that we will be able to get a large number of Irish taxpayers to comply with the requirements of a self-assessment taxation system. Without having gone through them in detail, I am now at the stage where I would welcome any kind of anti-avoidance provision. I no longer hold with many of the professional arguments that it would be an invasion of privacy to recover documents, etc. but if that is necessary it has to take place.

I think the Minister for being so patient. I have spoken at some length but this is a very long and complicated Bill. I ask the Minister at some stage to outline to us how it is intended to deal with the Bill on Committee Stage.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: As Deputy Noonan said, this is an extensive Bill and, of necessity, the Minister's speech was lengthy. I hope the House can agree to the setting up of a special committee of the House to deal with the Committee Stage of the Bill. Such a special committee would be more efficient in the way they do their work and would also be able to accord themselves more time than would otherwise normally be the case. In recognising the complexity of this Bill and the many sections which go to make it up I wish to put my request for the setting up of a special committee formally on the record of the House. I understand all parties are well disposed towards the idea and that the Whips are discussing it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick East) Mr. Noonan (Limerick East)
Speaker.P: (Limerick East): We agree to the proposal and the details will be worked out.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Ahern Mr. B. Ahern
Speaker.P: Because Deputy Noonan and Deputy Quinn have raised the issue, I wish to say that I am well-disposed towards the proposal. It is a reasonable proposal and hopefully we can work out suitable arrangements.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: I welcome the Minister's frank response.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Is that satisfactory? Agreed.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Quinn Mr. Quinn
Speaker.P: The Minister's speech is very interesting as it is really in three sections. The first section is a factual review of the economy at present both internationally and nationally. It concludes that in comparison with our neighbouring economies in the rest of the European Community, if we take the main indicators, excluding employment, by and large we are in a relatively well-placed position. I do not think I would necessarily disagree with the estimates for economic growth contained in the Minister's speech. However, a programme on one of the British television channels last night tended to revise downwards some of the estimates for growth for the EC, the United States and the UK. Obviously the person who wrote this speech must have been close to the sources which led to the conclusions reached in yesterday evenings analysis. By and large the first part of the Minister's speech effectively says that in comparison with other economies we are doing relatively well. Having regard to the fact that the United Kingdom economy shrunk in terms of growth last year while our economy grew by approximately 2 per cent we are in a relatively good position on the broad economic front with one exception, that is, employment.

MainHeading.P: In the second part of his speech under the heading “Employment” the Minister states:

But there is no denying that a daunting employment task lies before us — to earn the extra jobs we need; soundly based jobs; jobs which flow from producing more goods and services which can sell in the market place at home or abroad.

The Government in the budget have taken a number of steps to combat rising unemployment. First, the reductions in direct taxes will improve incentives, the rewards for enterprise and effort on a broad front. Second, we have agreed with the EC on the provision of substantial funds for a new employment subsidy scheme and for in-company training. I warmly welcome the fact that these schemes are receiving the full support of the FIE and other employer organisations and the ICTU. I strongly urge all employers to participate as fully as possible in these schemes.

Third, the area partnerships, envisaged in the Programme for Economic and Social Progress to combat long term unemployment through training, education and enterprise development are now in place in 12 pilot areas. The public agencies concerned have made the necessary arrangements; the estimated cost to the Exchequer is £60 million in 1992.

Fourth, a committee of Ministers assisted by a working party of officials and private sector individuals are examining the recommendations of the Industrial Policy Review Group and the Task Force on Employment.
But in the final analysis, there is only so much that any Government can do.
There is a kind of absolute underpinning assertion in this. The Minister continued:

They can make a key contribution by ensuring that their broad policy stand is conducive to employment growth. We have done so. They should ensure that, in its detail, Government policy minimises any disincentive effects on private effort and enterprise. We are doing so, not least through the substantial tax reforms in this and recent budgets. They should provide leadership on growth-oriented policies. Again, we have done so. But in the final analysis our progress will be determined by how well the private sector use the opportunity so created.

I would love to think that the person who wrote that section of the Minister's speech had spoken to the person who wrote the rest of his speech or worked with the people who produced the Finance Bill. I am paraphrasing in many respects some of the sentiments expressed earlier by Deputy Noonan because in broad measure I agree with his preliminary intellectual conclusion and analysis of the budget and its consequential Finance Bill. This is not an enterprise Finance Bill: it may be a cautious revenue protection and revenue gathering series of taxation measures. In view of the liberalisation of capital markets in 1993 there may be some legitimate reason for taking such an approach in some areas. As we move more towards a self-assessment taxation system it is also necessary to give extra powers to the Revenue Commissioners. There is a broad political culture out there, reinforced I have to say by the extraordinary revelations of the various tribunals and scandals which emerged during the past six months, which makes it absolutely essential for the Revenue Commissioners to have such powers, particularly when officials appointed by the High Court simply cannot get access to documentation to which they are entitled. Therefore, the culture in relation to those matters has changed.

Strictly speaking this is not a Finance Bill; it is a taxation Bill. It was certainly not produced by the Department of Finance. That Department should be renamed the Department of Revenue and Taxation. The ethos of the treasury runs right through this Bill. I have to say to the Minister — I will elaborate on this point tomorrow — that he should look at the part of his speech from which I quoted and, in particular, at the things he has claimed to have done. The Minister has simply not done the things he said he has done. The person who wrote that part of the Minister's speech did not read the rest of the Bill. Without playing intellectual games, one cannot in all honesty square the assertions set out in that part of the Minister's speech with the provisions in the Bill.

The Minister is making it much safer for anyone with any amount of money to put it safely on deposit at 10 per cent in toto. Other than winning the lottery, that is the best deal in town; it is absolutely copper-fastened and there is no risk whatsoever. In addition, the Minister is saying that a person who does not get the full set of lottery numbers can match five by putting surplus income in at a maximum of 27 per cent in toto and that this is the enterprise culture which will create jobs. Given the fall out from the bank's strike no new jobs will be created in the associated banks. Therefore, no additional employment will be created in the banks in counting these additional deposits.

I understand why the Minister has decided to protect revenue in the context of capital liberalisation in 1993. I understand why the banking institutions by and large have broadly welcomed the measures announced in the Finance Bill. Notwithstanding the hysterical denunciations of it by the Minister and his party when they were in Opposition, I understand the legitimate and understandable concerns anyone in the Minister's position must have to protect sources of revenue, particularly such an efficient source of revenue which the DIRT tax actually was. However, the results of similar liberalisation measures introduced in Britain by the then Chancellor for the Exchequer, Mr. Geoffrey Howe, are an indication as to the likely outflow of funds here. Maybe the Minister has been over cautious.
Debate adjourned.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Seán Treacy
Speaker.P: Seanad Éireann has passed the Environmental Protection Agency Bill, 1990, without amendment.

MainHeading.Title: Private Members' Business. - Mental Treatment (Amendment) Bill, 1992: Second Stage.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Fennell Mrs. Fennell
Speaker.P: I move: “That the Bill be now read a Second Time.”

I want to make some relevant comments to illustrate why the Bill was necessary. Under existing law — the Mental Treatment Act, 1945, and amending Acts of 1958 and 1961 — around 3,000 people per annum are committed involuntarily to psychiatric institutions. These people are detained on the application of a relative and the certification of one or two doctors. They are detained under what are referred to as reception orders. These are not reception orders in the judicial sense but medical authorisations for the detention of persons. There are two types of order, a reception order and a temporary reception order, and two types of person to whom they apply, chargeable and private patients under the 1945 Act. Chargeable patients are those whose treatments are paid for out of public funds, while private patients pay for their own treatments. A temporary reception order lasts for up to six months and the reception order lasts for more than six months. The vast majority of people detained under these orders would be seriously ill, mentally disturbed and-or violent. I know many families dealing with such cases who suffer great stress and upset, often over a long period and in many instances with poor support or financial help. I acknowledge the difficulties suffered by these people and their families and I commend all those working in our psychiatric institutions who do so with great dedication and care.

MainHeading.P: The legislation which is under scrutiny relates to another group of people, those against whom detention orders are made but who are inappropriately held. In examining the 1945 Act, it is evident that its provisions have been abused by causing people to be committed who were not insane, violent or dangerous. The motivation of the relative who committed them was at last questionable. Many of these people are committed to resolve a domestic dispute. In the cases with which I have been involved the provisions of the Act were misguidedly used as a solution to marital breakdown problems.

Some people will recall the Adjournment Debate last June during which I highlighted the situation of a young mother from County Dublin who had been forcibly removed from her home on a summer afternoon and detained in St. Patrick's Hospital. A week previously she had obtained a protection order against her husband. Her marriage was most unstable and unhappy and she was under great stress. Her need was for a legal separation and the possibility of making a life separate from her husband. Her need was not for a detention order which removed her to a mental hospital.

My experience of such cases goes back well before June last year. In 1975 I was contacted by two women, one a mother of seven from Galway and the other a mother of 12 from Dublin, with whose cases I became very familiar. They were both in marriages which were violent and damaging but at that time there was no acceptance that a woman could leave, even in a very bad marriage situation. This was prior to the enactment of the family law Acts by the Coalition Government in the seventies. One possible relief for many women was when their husbands deserted to England. This was very common in the seventies and was called divorce Irish-style. The only other relief these women got was when their husbands died and they became widows. While unhappy marriages were not as uncommon as now — or at least we were not aware of them — the hardship for the wife and mother living in a dead marriage was considerable and unrelenting. In that context I was personally involved with a number of cases, but specifically with the two I have mentioned.

After a first committal by their husbands, the women endured what was in effect a revolving door syndrome, living in fear of being recommitted if they did not behave themselves. There were many in the seventies for whom the first battered wives home in Harcourt Street which opened in 1974 became a refuge from this type of home life and it represented their chance to make a new life with their children. The women I met through that refuge all recounted the same story. The signing doctors did not know them. They may have been neighbouring doctors and may have known the women vaguely but not as patients. They were very often the husband's GP. The doctors did not examine the women, most of whom had the awful experience of having the committal completed with the help of an ambulance and the Garda. Once inside the pshychiatric institution they were refused access to a telephone or permission to have visitors.

Many of those women afterwards lost custody of their children and they lived lives of isolation, feeling outcast because of their experience. When they tried to get an explanation from the hospital about their committal or to get copies of the documentation involved they came up against resilient opposition in every case. They were told they had no rights under the 1945 Act to such information.

Until the case of last June was brought to my attention it was my belief that amending legislation was in place which had introduced necessary safeguards against inappropriate or wrongful committal. I was most surprised to discover that this was not the case and that the 1945 Act, which had caused such difficulties to women in the seventies, was still the statute involved. I discovered that the 1981 Mental Services Act included the necessary reforms to prevent abuse but that it was never brought into force. The time for debate counted for nothing. I will return to that legislation later.

The cases I have referred to and the numerous other cases about which I have been contacted by individuals, psychiatric workers and relatives, show an urgent need for reform. It is the function of law to provide clear guidance to those working in the psychiatric services and to provide firm safeguards against malpractice to users of the services. That is the purpose of this Bill. People with mental health problems are regrettably the poor relatives of the health services. Mental health has a low priority in terms of budgetary or monetary planning. There is a great need for broad-based reform which would concentrate on reducing overcrowding in our institutions, developing community facilities and changing the nature of our psychiatric institutions, many of which date back 200 years, from the isolationism of the past to greater integration for mentally ill people and their carers in the communities in which they live. I hope this debate focuses on those factors as well as on the provisions of the Bill. These guidelines are well documented in the 1984 Department of Health report, Planning For The Future.

I repeat that much too little has been done to implement the recommendations of the 1984 report, and successive Ministers for Health must stand indicted. I am concentrating here on an area which I feel is urgent and for which there is public concern. There has been unease over the years about abuse and the possibility of abuse in the 1945 Act. Incidents have been well documented in recent weeks by the media and by RTE. The need for urgent change has been identified. I appeal to all sides of the House to support my proposals and allow long overdue changes to be put in place.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Mental Treatment Acts, 1945 to 1961, where they deal with reception orders. In section 3 there is a misprint on line 14 in that the word “Part” should be substituted by “Sections” to read “Sections 14, 15 and 16 of the Principal Act”. This section aims to end the practice in the 1945 Act under which chargeable or public patients are treated differently from private patients. There is no reason for safeguards to be different as between sectors. The fundamental freedom of the individual is in question in both instances and the basic principle demands equal and maximum safeguards for all, regardless of means.

Section 4 of the Bill provides for the establishment of mental health review boards, with one board in each health board area. These boards would consist of three persons, a barrister or solicitor, a medical practitioner and a lay person, all to be appointed by the Minister for Health. Section 5 deals with the work of the review board and how applications are made. Where an application for a review comes from a detainee, his or her parent, spouse or offspring or from the Minister for Health or the President of the High Court, the review cannot be refused under this section. However, it shall be at the discretion of the board to grant or refuse the review if made by some other person.

Section 6 deals with the outcome of the examination by the board and the decisions at which they may arrive. Section 7 involves a review of a person who has been conditionally discharged. Section 8 puts an onus on the board to seek a report from the medical officer in charge of each psychiatric centre for each person who has been in detention for a period of two years and make recommendations that he or she shall not be discharged or be discharged conditionally or transferred to care accommodation more suitable to his or her condition. Section 9 provides that the medical officer in charge of a psychiatric centre shall, in making the order, give that person a copy of the order and all documents relating to his or her detention. It also deals with providing documents on request after the person is discharged.

Section 10 repeals sections 259 and 260 of the Principal Act, 1945. Section 259 imposes a time bar on proceedings which may not be instituted after six months from the end of detention. This is quite an extraordinary limiting factor. It contrasts with normal periods of limitation for seeking civil actions, which for false imprisonment is six years and for actions for personal injuries, three years. Section 260 provides that civil proceedings cannot be taken under the 1945 Act except with leave of the High Court, and that leave shall not be granted unless the High Court is satisfied that there are substantial grounds for contending that the person against whom such proceedings are being brought acted in bad faith or without reasonable care.

As outlined, I am sure nobody could disagree with the thrust of this Bill or deny that it deals with basic safeguards and protection of civil liberty. I am dealing with the Minister for Health who is as informed and, I feel certain, as concerned about what is happening as I am. I confidently hope that this Bill will not suffer the same fate as the 1981 Act either by being rejected in total or being cast and left in deep freeze to await indefinitely the necessary ministerial directions to put it into force. I want this House to deal with the reality of our mental health problems, acknowledging that the people concerned are not able to articulate their needs in many cases and depend heavily on legislators to upgrade legislation, safeguard their rights and improve their conditions.

This Bill cannot be answered with vague promises. I am not convinced that we need White or Green Papers in order to take the action that I have outlined as necessary. I would suggest to the Minister that the day is long gone when painting the railings of our psychiatric institutions can substitute for real fundamental changes in our services and in our law. I am particularly asking that the Minister, in his response, give an honest appraisal of the aborted 1981 Act in view of the fact that there is such a degree of public confusion and disbelief about that Act. There is no precedent for what happened with that legislation. What were the reasons it was never put into force? Are there sections that could be activated now through ministerial order? What was the outcome of the review of the legislation in the Department since 1981, as referred to in “Planning For The Future?”

I am aware that the medical profession opposed some of the provisions in that legislation. Doctors have told me that their fears and views have to be reasonably considered. One area of concern to them is the need for speedy action in times of crisis, when a mentally ill person is being disruptive and violent. They say it would be a very difficult procedure to demand in the legislation that two GPs sign the certification after examination. This would be particularly difficult in the case of a crisis at night, at weekends or, as was stressed in the original debate in the 1981 Act, in a rural area. I do not believe that these are insurmountable problems. I accept that there is a difficulty in this regard and I suggest that an amendment be introduced on Committee Stage along the lines proposed by the Irish Council for Civil Liberties in their report of the Mental Health Bill, 1981, which states:

The Bill should provide crises intervention facilities to be made available by each Health Board. These might take the form of a team on stand-by in cases of emergency and include at least a Doctor and a Nurse suitably qualified. In such circumstances, two accredited members of a crises intervention team should be empowered to sign a recommendation for a reception under Section 19 in lieu of two G.P.s provided they were satisfied that a crisis genuinely existed.

I believe that a satisfactory provision could be put in place recognising the reality of these cases which, as I said earlier, represent the majority of the numbers at present detained annually. I am aware that this problem was encountered in amending legislation in the UK and elsewhere. They have resolved the problem satisfactorily and perhaps we should look at that before putting legislation in place.

Let us look for a moment at the Health (Mental Services) Act, 1981. Many of the provisions of this amending legislation undoubtedly would have contributed to the rights of detained persons, most notably in requiring the written recommendation of two registered general practitioners for a reception order and dropping the distinction between public and private patients in this regard. Under the 1945 Act, which came into force in 1947, the procedure that applies to public patients is different from that applying to private patients. This is unacceptable to public opinion and it was recommended that it be dropped in the 1981 Act.

The 1981 Act also requires that a general practitioner who makes a recommendation is required to inform the person to whom it relates of his intention. The Act required the medical officer in charge of the psychiatric centre to give the person detained a copy of the reception order together with the recommendation for reception and a copy of any extension order. The Act also requires the medical officer to give the person a statement of his rights and entitlements under the Act. He is further obliged to provide persons detained with the necessary facilities for writing, delivering and posting letters. We would all agree I am sure, that these measures should be a fundamental right of any patient detained. The Act also proposed the abolition of the time limit on the institution of court proceedings, as I propose in my amending Private Members' Bill.

While the 1981 Act was an improved measure to protect essential civil liberties, it has to be acknowledged that it did not provide the complete answer for legislative reform, as one would have expected from the first major reforming legislation on mental health in 35 years. For instance, it failed to define mental disorder, it did not lay down the criteria for what should be considered an examination and alternatives to committal were not discussed.
In their comments and proposals on the Health Mental Services Bill, 1981, the Irish Council for Civil Liberties said in October 1980:

The Bill is a short document of some 20 pages, reflecting the narrowness of its scope, especially in comparison with the existing legislation which is a 130 page publication and which will be repealed by the Bill.

The Irish Council for Civil Liberties feel that major safeguards and protection need to be included in law and, therefore, subject to full open debate, rather than subject to ministerial regulations or local practice. They said:
Moreover law can do more than rationalise accepted practise, (sic) progressive legislation can act to stimulate progressive developments in the Mental Health Services.

I now wish to deal with two related areas. I am seriously concerned that no reports of the inspector of mental hospitals have been published since 1979. The Minister will be aware that we have debated this already in this House. I now see how this is related to the 1981 Act. Interestingly enough, that Act dropped the requirement in sections 247 and 248 of the 1945 Act that the Minister and the Oireachtas would receive an annual report on all mental institutions, including the Central Mental Hospital and private mental hospitals and on the care of patients in all those institutions. The anomaly we now have is that no reports have been issued by the inspector since 1982, which dealt with the years up to 1979. It seems that the inspector of mental hospitals is operating under the provisions of the 1981 Act, which did not come into force and is ignoring entirely his obligations under the 1945 Act where this is his statutory duty. This is an extraordinary situation and I am sure the Minister must agree that it must be resolved right away.

I question how mental health services can function properly without the statistics, the facts and figures, contained in these reports. Indeed, I read the last one published in 1982 and found it informative and reassuring. However, I would have to question what access people have to statistics if they cannot put their hands on an up-to-date report which one would expect in this important area.
The proposal in this Bill will give effect to Ireland's duties under the European Convention on Human Rights. Article 5 (1) of the convention provides that:
Everyone has the right to liberty and security of person. Nobody shall be deprived of his liberties save in the following cases and in accordance with procedures prescribed by law.

Article 5 (1) (e) states two broad conditions for depriving a person of liberty on mental health grounds and the detention must be in accordance with a procedure prescribed by law and must be a lawful detention of a person of unsound mind. The European Court of Human Rights held in the Wintwerp case, 1979, that any measure depriving a person of his liberty should issue and be executed by an appropriate authority and should not be arbitrary; paragraph 37 requires that the domestic law procedure be fair and proper and that it be complied with. We are not doing this under the 1945 Act and, therefore, we are in contravention of our obligations under the European Convention on Human Rights.
Article 5 (4) of the convention provides:

Everyone who is deprived of his liberty by a detention shall be entitled to take proceedings by which the lawfulness of his detention shall be decided speedily by a court and his release ordered if the detention is not lawful.

It, therefore, seems appropriate in the interest of carrying out our obligations under the European Convention on Human Rights that Irish legislators should entertain and enact the proposls to establish mental health review boards, as is proposed in my Bill.

The debate on this Private Members' Bill will be watched very carefully tonight, tomorrow night and next week by a number of groups and interested parties. Indeed, the Minister's response tonight is very much anticipated. We in Fine Gael are committed to this Bill and we sincerely hope it will be accepted and will be given effect in legislation, but there is broad consensus among those who are equally concerned. Among the groups who support the measures in the Bill is Women's Aid, which operate refuges in and outside Dublin. In an article in The Irish Times in June 1991 Ms. McDermott commented on the reality for some women who come to her refuge:

Ms. McDermott said that the use of threats of committal by husbands against their wives was a large problem so far as Women's Aid was concerned. The threat was usually coupled with a warning that if the women were committed, they would lose their children.
The use of the threat seemed to be more common among middle class than among working class people, she said.
The threat of committal was one of the ways in which some men kept control over their wives. “Fear is the greatest weapon of all.” These wives often found themselves trapped, she said.

In some cases, the man would do things — like hiding the woman's shoes — to make her gradually doubt her own sanity. In other cases, years of stress, beatings and threats would lead the woman to seek medication and this in itself would become another piece of evidence that she was mentally ill.

Ms McDermott said she supported proposals for change. In a press release Ms. McDermott said Women's Aid is an organisation that provides support and accommodation for women who have been physically, mentally and sexually abused in their homes and they welcomed the Mental Treatment (Amendment) Bill 1992. The press release states:

Over the last 18 years we have dealt with a number of women who have suffered under the 1945 Mental Health Act. It is our experience that women who have sought barring orders against violent husbands have often found themselves committed to a psychiatric institution against their will.
We believe the 1945 Act as it stands is open to abuse, particularly in relation to the most vulnerable people in our society.

Therefore we urge all political parties to support the Mental Treatment (Amendment) Bill, 1992, proposed by Fine Gael to ensure that proper legislation is enacted to amend the law which patently does not afford protection to this country's citizens. This Act must be amended to ensure that it cannot be used as a threat to women who attempt to protect themselves from violent husbands in the invoking of current legislation in the family law area.

It is interesting to note a common thread running through the reports of people who are the victims of that legislation. Other groups and people have supported it. In a “Today Tonight” programme, psychiatrist Professor Anthony Clare was in no doubt whatever about the need for reform of the 1945 Act. He talked about the need for transition from the custodial form of treatment which has been traditional in this country to the therapeutic which is now accepted in modern medicine to be the correct approach. He said his medical colleagues had no cause to fear change.
In a letter to The Irish Times on 25 January 1992 the administrator of the Schizophrenia Association of Ireland said:

Involuntary commital is traumatic for both the patient and family and unfortunately in some cases it is necessary. However, it need not be the only way. Ideally one should aim for voluntary admission as it is not hard to understand that treatment received voluntarily is much more likely to be effective. More attention might be paid to ways of exploring helpful routes to voluntary admission. For instance, our experience is that self help groups can help people to acknowledge the need for psychiatric care.
Following discharge the level of care available varies throughout the country. Today the family is usually the backbone of community care.

The administrator of the Schizophrenia Association of Ireland went on to give details of the support services they would like. Even though they are a group who would have first-hand experience of the need for crisis detention, they accept there is need for reform and that involuntary committal should not be the first line of action.

In the past year a separate organisation has been formed, called Wrongfully Institutionalised People, who are campaigning for change and support for this measure. They know they cannot do anything to redress the injustices that have been perpetrated against them over the years but they are determined that this practice ceases and that other people will not be victimised in the same way as they were. I would like to quote another psychiatrist, Dr. Michael Corry, who feels very strongly about this Act. In a letter in The Irish Times of 8 March 1990 he said:

Why doctors co-operate with this process is more than just a matter for their own conscience. It places them in an untenable position, as in essence, whether they like it or not, they fulfil a powerful political role in society which overrides their medical one. It raises three fundamental questions which cannot be fudged, namely: how is it possible to treat someone against their will? How can an atmosphere of trust develop between the doctor and his client when there is power on one side and fear on the other?
